titleStmt.title: Newgates Garland
Being
A New Ballad
Shewing
How Mr 08. Jonathan Wild's Throat was cut from Ear to Ear with a
Penknife by Mr 08. Blake alias Blewskin the bold Highwayman,

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: To the Tune of the Cut-Purse.
Ye Fellows of Newgate, whose Fingers are nice,
In diving in Pockets, or cogging of Dice,
Ye Sharpers so rich, who can buy of the Noose,
Ye honester poor Rogues, who die in your Shoes,Attend and draw near,Good news ye shall hear,
How Jonathan's Throat was cut, from Ear to Ear,
How Blewskin's sharp Penknife hath set you at Ease,
And every Man round me may rob, if they please.2.
When to the Old Bailey this Blewskin was led,
He held up his Hand, his Indictment was read,
Loud rattl'd his Chains, near him Jonathan stood,
For full forty Pounds, was the Price of his Blood:Then hopeless of Life,He drew his Penknife,And made a sad Widdow of Jonathan's Wife,
But forty Pounds paid her, her Grief shall appease,
And every man round me may rob, if they please.3.
Some say there are Courtiers of highest Renown,
Who steal the King's Gold, and leave him but a Crown,
Some say there are Peers, and some Parliament Men,
Who meet once a Year to rob Courtiers again.Let them all take their Swing,To pillage the KingAnd get a Blew Ribbon instead of a String.
Now Blewskin's sharp Penknife hath set you at Ease
And every man round me may rob, if they please.4.
Knaves of Old to hide Guilt by their cunning Inventions
Call'd Briberies Grants and──plain Robberies Pensions:
Physitians and Lawyers (who take their Degrees
To be Learned Rogues) call'd their Pilfering──Fees;Since this happy Day,Now every man mayRob (as safe as in Office) upon the Highway.
For Blewskin's sharp Penknife, &c.5.
Some cheat in the Customs, some rob the Excise
But he who robs both, is esteemed most wise,Church-Wardens who always have dreaded the Halter
As yet only venture to steal from the Altar:But now to get Gold,They may be more bold,And rob on the Highway since Jonathan's cold.
For Blewskin's sharp Penknife, &c.6.
Some by Publick Revenues which pass'd through their Hands,
Have Purchas'd clean Houses, and bought dirty Lands,
Some to steal from a Charity think it no Sin,
Which at home (says the Proverb) does always beginBut if ever you be,Assign'd a Trustee,Treat not Orphans like Masters of the Chancery:
But take the Highway and more honestly seise,
For every man round me may rob, if they please.7.
What a Pother has here been with Wood and his Brass
Who would modestly make a few Half-pennies pass.
The Patent is good, and the Precedents old
For Diomede changed his Copper for Gold.But if Ireland despise,Thy new Half-pennies,With more safety to rob on the Road I advise.
For Blewskin's sharp Penknife has set you at Ease
And ev'ry Man round me may rob, if they please.Y13-760L
